Hmmm....there's usually a way around it if you want to
test something, even if they are in different
packages.  For instance, maybe the private methods
should really be pulled out and placed in their own
class, which could have public methods, but the old
class would have a private instance of the new class.

My take on this . . . put them in the same package, or
don't, user inner classes, or don't, whatever (I've
seen too many flames about this issue to last me a
while) . . . just make sure you test what should be
tested.  There's always a way to make it (more)
testable.

-Eric

--- Vladimir Bossicard <vladimir@...> wrote:
> > I see no need to test methods other than public
> <snip> I'll write 
> 
>  > test methods for the protected methods as well.
> 
> So why do you test protected methods if there's no
> need to test methods 
> other than public?  Simply because it depends. 
> Sometimes you want to 
> test protected methods, sometimes you don't.
> 
> My point is: placing tests classes so that it is
> _impossible_ to test 
> protected methods is a "bad" decision because you
> restrict your 
> flexibility.  By placing test classes in the same
> package, you still 
> have that flexibility, but you don't have to use it
> if you don't want to.
>
